sections.summary: Net Liquidity is the 'fuel' of the modern financial system. Defined as the Fed's Balance Sheet minus the Treasury General Account (TGA) and Reverse Repo (RRP), it represents the actual amount of cash available to banks and investors. Since 2020, its correlation with the S&P 500 has recently surpassed that of earnings or GDP.
sections.deep_dive: Historically, central banks controlled the economy via interest rates (price of money). In the post-QE era, they control it via the Balance Sheet (quantity of money). In 2026, as the RRP facility drains significantly and TGA volatility increases due to sovereign debt refinancing, Net Liquidity has become the single most critical variable for predicting 'Minsky Moments'. The decoupling between traditional valuations and price action is often explained by this metric.

sections.forecast_risks: The primary risk is a 'TGA Shock' where the Treasury drains massive liquidity to fund emergency conflicts, crashing asset prices overnight. Upside risk involves the Fed ending QT early to cap yields, unleashing a 'Liquidity Tsunami' that fuels a hyper-growth bubble.
sections.gms_conclusion: Bearish Divergence detected. While the AI productivity utility is real, the liquidity fuel tank is flashing red. We recommend reducing leverage impacting high-beta assets until Net Liquidity re-establishes an uptrend.
